verses.text: A wise son listens to his father’s instruction, but a scoffer does not hear rebuke.
verses.comment: The contrast between the wise and the scoffer highlights the importance of receiving correction for spiritual growth. Obedience to rightful authority mirrors obedience to God (Heb. 12:7–11).

verses.text: From the fruit of his mouth a man eats good, but the soul of the treacherous feeds on violence.
verses.comment: Words produce real outcomes. The contrast points to the need for cultivating virtues in speech (Matt. 12:36–37).

verses.text: He who guards his mouth protects his life, but he who opens his lips wide comes to ruin.
verses.comment: Self-control in speech is foundational for spiritual maturity (Jas. 3:2–10).

verses.text: The soul of the sluggard craves and has nothing, but the soul of the diligent is abundantly supplied.
verses.comment: Diligence points to cooperation with God’s grace (Phil. 2:12–13). Restlessness of the sluggard is spiritual as well as physical.

verses.text: A righteous man hates lying, but the wicked bring shame and disgrace.
verses.comment: Hatred of lying aligns with the virtue of truthfulness, a core moral teaching (Eph. 4:25).

verses.text: Righteousness guards the one whose way is blameless, but wickedness overthrows the sinner.
verses.comment: A blameless life is a spiritual shelter. See also Ps. 25:21 for God’s protection of the upright.

verses.text: One pretends to be rich, yet has nothing; another pretends to be poor, yet has great wealth.
verses.comment: True spiritual riches are interior. Christ’s poverty is a model (2 Cor. 8:9).

verses.text: A man’s riches may ransom his life, but a poor man hears no threat.
verses.comment: Riches can bring earthly security, but spiritual security comes in humility before God (Matt. 6:19–21).

verses.text: The light of the righteous shines brightly, but the lamp of the wicked will be put out.
verses.comment: Light symbolizes moral goodness and points toward Christ as the true light (John 8:12).

verses.text: By pride comes only strife, but wisdom is with those who take advice.
verses.comment: Humility opens us to wisdom. The Church has always taught the necessity of wise spiritual counsel (Sir. 6:34).

verses.text: Wealth gained hastily will dwindle, but whoever gathers little by little will increase it.
verses.comment: Steady effort and stewardship are commended over greed or seeking shortcuts.

verses.text: Hope deferred makes the heart sick, but a desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
verses.comment: ‘Tree of life’ recalls Genesis 3:22 and looks forward to its fulfillment in Christ (Rev. 2:7).

verses.text: Whoever despises the word brings destruction on himself, but he who fears the commandment will be rewarded.
verses.comment: Obedience to instruction is salvific—a principle seen in Deut. 5:29 and Jesus’ teaching in John 14:23.

verses.text: The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, turning one away from the snares of death.
verses.comment: A source of life is seen as God’s wisdom, anticipating the waters of teaching and sacramental grace (John 4:14).

verses.text: Good sense wins favor, but the way of the treacherous is hard.
verses.comment: Moral wisdom brings blessings; folly leads to bitter consequences.

verses.text: Every prudent man acts with knowledge, but a fool flaunts his folly.
verses.comment: Wisdom teaches humility; one should seek counsel and hide folly, not make it public (Sir. 20:30).

verses.text: A wicked messenger falls into trouble, but a faithful envoy brings healing.
verses.comment: Healing here suggests the spiritual healing offered by faithful ministers (Isa. 52:7).

verses.text: Poverty and disgrace come to him who ignores instruction, but whoever heeds correction is honored.
verses.comment: This wisdom points toward openness to spiritual guidance and correction (Heb. 12:11).

verses.text: A desire fulfilled is sweet to the soul, but to turn away from evil is an abomination to fools.
verses.comment: Desire fulfilled alludes to spiritual desires met in Christ. Fools hate discipline and repentance.

verses.text: Whoever walks with the wise becomes wise, but the companion of fools will suffer harm.
verses.comment: Spiritual friendship is crucial for growing in wisdom and faith (Sir. 6:36).

verses.text: Disaster pursues sinners, but the righteous are repaid with good.
verses.comment: There are natural and spiritual consequences for sin and virtue.

verses.text: A good man leaves an inheritance to his children’s children, but the sinner’s wealth is stored up for the righteous.
verses.comment: Spiritual inheritance is valued as much as material, pointing towards passing on faith and blessing.

verses.text: Abundant food is in the fallow ground of the poor, but it is swept away by injustice.
verses.comment: God’s justice demands care for the poor. Systemic injustice is condemned (Isa. 5:8).

verses.text: Whoever spares the rod hates his son, but he who loves him is diligent to discipline him.
verses.comment: Discipline is an act of love, forming virtuous habits. See also Heb. 12:6.

verses.text: The righteous has enough to satisfy his appetite, but the belly of the wicked suffers want.
verses.comment: God provides for those who walk in righteousness (Matt. 6:33). Christ is the bread that truly satisfies (John 6:35).
